p: During the first four waves of the epidemic, the H7N9 virus was classified as a LPAI virus and caused no overt clinical symptoms in poultry. This impeded attempts to develop accurate viral surveillance [ 32]. Moreover, in light of the associated economic losses, some agricultural authorities and members of the poultry industry contested the conclusion that poultry were the source of human infections [ 33]. These individuals emphasized that there was insufficient evidence to prove that the poultry were the original source of the virus [ 34]. It was further argued that the H7N9 influenza virus should neither be named as avian influenza nor should the government report every human infection to the general public [ 34, 35]. This dissent represented a significant obstacle for information transparency and inter-departmental collaboration.
